Legal_Issue: Whether the plaintiff had a duty to proceed with reasonable dispatch after obtaining an interlocutory injunction
Evidence_Assessment: No new evidence of harm presented
Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to demonstrate diligence in pursuing trial
Legal_Rule: Under Rule 469(5) of the Federal Court Rules, interlocutory injunctions can be rescinded due to change in circumstances or undue delay
Procedural_Issue: Prolonged delay in bringing action to trial after obtaining injunction
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged trademark infringement by Apotex and Novopharm
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; case dismissed on procedural grounds
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Defendants prejudiced by delay in litigation
Key_Evidence_Considered: Duration of delay (over three years without progress)
Legal_Framework: Federal Court Rules, Rule 469(5); Trade-marks Act
Court_Result: Injunctions lifted, defendants allowed to re-enter market
Defendant_Response: Motion to dissolve injunctions based on undue delay
Remedy_Sought: Prevention of sale of similar products through injunction
Resolution_Mechanism: Judicial determination on motion to dissolve injunction
Legal_Provision: Rule 469(5), Federal Court Rules; Trade-marks Act
Legal_Provision_Cited: Rule 469(5) of the Federal Court Rules
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Undue delay in prosecution of claim
Outcome_of_Review: Injunctions dissolved due to lack of diligence
